newsitem.title: UK: Gremlin drops to discount on LSE debut. [CORRECTED 14:56 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Gremlin drops to discount on LSE debut. [CORRECTED 14:56 GMT]

text.p: Shares in computer and video game software company Gremlin Group Plc on Thursday dived to an 8.5 percent discount on their first day of dealings on the London Stock Exchange, dealers said.
Gremlin shares, issued at 159p, dropped 13-1/2p to 145-1/2p by 1405 GMT in volume of 717,000 (correcting figure from 717 million to 717,000) shares.
Dealers said private investors were behind the initial selling as the stock tumbled to 135-1/2p soon after the shares opened for trading at 0730 GMT.
But dealers said the shares rallied as institutional buyers emerged.
Gremlin makes games for PC CD Rom and for dedicated games consoles such as the Sony PlayStation, Sega Saturn and Nintendo 64.
The Sheffield-based group made pre-tax profits of 2.5 million stg from sales of 11 million stg in the nine months ended April 30 1997.
In a separate development, Gremlin said on Thursday it had appointed Cees Zwaard as commercial director with immediate effect.
The group said Zwaard had joined from multi media company VCI Plc and would be responsible for the development of Gremlin's commercial strategy and its implementation.
